Lavrientieva 5 Novosibirsk 630090 Russia b Novosibirsk State University, Pirogova Str. 2, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russia Novosibirsk State University Pirogova Str. 2 Novosibirsk 630090 Russia c Chemistry Department, Moscow State University, Leninskiye Gory 1-3, Moscow, 119899, Russia Chemistry Department, Moscow State University Leninskiye Gory 1-3 Moscow 119899 Russia ⁎ Corresponding author at: Boreskov Insitute of Catalysis SB RAS, Pr. Lavrientieva 5, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russia. Graphical abstract Isotopic oxygen exchange on the surface of Mo-V-Te-Nb oxide catalysts was studied. Catalyst samples contained more than 95% of (i) orthorhombic phase M1, (ii) pseudo hexagonal phase M2, or (iii) layered phase with structure Me5O14 (Me – Mo, V, Nb). Two forms of exchangeable oxygen were found on the surface, i.e. strongly bonded lattice oxygen and relatively weakly bonded adsorbed oxygen. According to in situ studies with isotope 18O adsorbed oxygen leads to deep oxidation products, while lattice oxygen participates mainly in the partial oxidation processes. Weakly bonded oxygen concentration decreases in series: Me5O14 >M2>M1 and thus selectivity towards partial oxidation increases. Keywords Selective oxidation MoVTeNb oxide catalysts Isotope oxygen exchange SSITKA 1 Introduction For many years selective oxidation of paraffins to olefins, aldehydes, acids and nitriles attracts a lot of research attention. Discovered in the 90s MoVTeNb oxide system has provided essential progress in the field [1,2]. This system contains several oxide phases – orthorhombic M1, hexagonal M2, and Me5O14 structure phase. These phases differ by chemical composition and final structure arrangement. Orthorhombic phase M1 appears to be the most active and selective in (ammo)oxidation of propane, in oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane [3,4] and in ethanol oxidation [5]. According to Ueda et al. the structural unit arrangement in the a–b plane of the catalysts is dominant in the genesis of the oxidation activity, and existence of the 7-membered ring site in the Mo3VO x based catalyst is indispensable for the oxidation activity [6]. The role of phase composition of system MoVTeNb in the partial oxidation of alkanes is under discussion [7], however, recent investigations focus mainly on the surface structure, active site composition and oxidation reaction mechanism [8–13]. Surface oxygen state is an important factor influencing reaction selectivity at heterogeneous catalytic oxidation of hydrocarbons by molecular oxygen. It is widely accepted that weakly bonded electrophilic oxygen O2 − or O− participate in deep oxidation, while strongly bonded nucleophilic lattice oxygen O2− is responsible for selective oxidation [14–16]. For example, according to [17] in oxidative dehydrogenation of propane and ethane on vanadium catalysts lattice oxygen participates in formation of olefins, while “super-surface” oxygen provides CO2. W. Ueda considers that bridged lattice oxygen between highly distorted Mo and V octahedra forming the 7-memebered ring unit is responsible for selective oxidation on the Mo3VO x catalysts [6]. Using pulse technique Kubo et al. showed that the oxidative ammonolysis of propane on the orthorhombic MoVTeNb phase M1 involves “surface lattice” oxygen on a–b plane [18]. At oxidation of propane, propylene, acrolein and ethanol on individual phases partial oxidation selectivity decreases according to the same sequence: M1>M2>Mo5O14 [4,5]. In order to reveal interrelation between the oxygen state on MoVTeNb catalysts and their selectivity we have studied the kinetics of isotopic oxygen exchange on catalyst samples containing mostly individual phases. Isotopic exchange is a well known method for catalyst oxygen characterization, allowing to reveal various surface oxygen species possessing different activity, and to estimate their concentration and bond energy. However, it is necessary to distinct what oxygen species are responsible for definite reaction routs. For the purpose we have chosen SSITKA (Steady-State Isotopic Transient Kinetic Analysis) using label 18O. We have taken selective ethanol oxidation to acetic acid as test reaction due to the relative simplicity of mass spectroscopy characterization of isotope product composition. Using the isotope-kinetic parameters of surface oxygen species on individual phases, we have managed to identify in situ oxygen species responsible for either partial oxidation or deep oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Samples preparation and characterization Mo1V0.3Te0.23Nb0.12 catalyst was prepared by mixing the aqueous solutions of ammonium heptamolybdate, ammonium metavanadate, telluric acid and niobium oxalate (T =35–40°C, pH 3) with subsequent suspension drying in laboratory spray dryer (Buchi-290, T inlet =220°C and T outlet =110°C). Dry powder was heated in air flow at 320°C during a short time period and then in He at 600°C for 2h [19]. M1 phase was obtained by treating the Mo1V0.3Te0.23Nb0.12 catalyst with 15% hydrogen peroxide. According to [20], ternary-component phase M2 is formed during the high temperature treatment of Mo1V0.3Te0.23Nb0.12 catalyst. M2 phase with atomic ratio Mo1V0.3Te0.23 was prepared by spraying ternary MoVTe solution. Then solid precursor was heated at 500°C in He [21]. Mo5−x (V/Nb) x O14 phase was obtained by MoVNb suspension evaporation (atomic ratio Mo1V0.3Nb0.37) followed by calcination at 550°C in air flow [22]. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using Cu Ka (λ =1.5418Å) radiation with Siemens D500 diffractometer equipped with diffracted-beam graphite monochromator. Data were recorded in a 2u range 5–65° (step size 0.02°, time 5s). Phase content was calculated with Ritweld method. 2.2 Oxygen isotopic exchange Oxygen isotopic exchange was performed in a temperature-programmed mode (TPIE). Desired gas composition containing a non-equilibrium mixture of oxygen isotopes (50%16O2, 45%18O2, and 5%16O18O, overall O2 concentration being 10% in He) was controlled by mass-flow sensor. Total gas flow rate was 45ml/min. Gas was passed through a plug-flow reactor placed inside a tube furnace. Samples (0.5g) were heated up to 550°C with a rate of 2.5K/min. The grain size of catalyst was 0.5–0.25mm. Outlet gas flow part went to mass-spectrometer, and ion current at mass numbers 32 (16O2), 34 (16O18O) and 36 (18O2) was recorded simultaneously with measuring of sample temperature by thermocouple. Isotopic composition of gaseous oxygen was calculated on the base of mass-spectrometric data: f 32 = I 32 ∑ I i , f 34 = I 34 ∑ I i , f 36 = I 36 ∑ I i ; α = 2 × I 36 + I 34 2 × ∑ I i , where f 32, f 34 and f 36 – molecular fraction of isotopic oxygen molecules 16O2, 16O18O and 18O2, respectively; α – atomic fraction 18O in gaseous oxygen; I 32, I 34 and I 36 are parent peaks at m/e 32:34:36, ∑I i = I 32 + I 34 + I 36. In order to determine concentrations of isotopic molecules, the corresponding molecular isotopic fraction f i was multiplied by overall oxygen concentration in a feed gas. Note, the constancy of overall O2 concentration during heating was controlled by the sum I 32 + I 34 + I 36. 2.3 SSITKA study of ethanol oxidation Ethanol oxidation was performed in the same reactor placed in a furnace. Catalyst pretreatment consisted in a heating in 4% O2 +He mixture at 300°C for an hour. Catalyst sample weight was 0.3g. The feed gas consisted of C2H5OH (1vol%) and O2 (2vol%) in He. Prior SSITKA experiments the chromatographic analysis of outlet gas mixture was carried out at different reaction times and temperatures. In addition to acetic acid and carbon oxides, a noticeable amount of acetaldehyde and ethyl acetate was observed in the reaction products at incomplete conversion. When approaching the 100% conversion, the concentrations of acetaldehyde and ethyl acetate for the M1 and Me5O14 phases vanish, while the selectivity to acetic acid reached 85%. At the same time, for the M2 phase the main product was acetaldehyde even at a virtually complete conversion (>99%), and the selectivity to acetic acid was lower 20% in a range of temperatures and contact times under study. Isotopic experiments were carried out as follows: as steady state was achieved in C2H5OH+O2 +He flow, gas mixture was stepwise replaced by the same one though containing 18O2, isotope 18O content being 70%. Current isotopic composition of reaction products was monitored by mass spectrometry analysis. The presence of acetaldehyde and ethyl acetate in gas flow essentially impedes mass spectrometry analysis, since ethyl acetate spectrum overlaps with that of acetic acid, and acetaldehyde spectrum overlaps with that of carbon dioxide. When studying the M1 and Me5O14 phases, the overlapping of spectra was avoided due to carrying out SSITKA study at high ethanol conversion, when the concentrations of acetaldehyde and ethyl acetate were negligibly small. Moreover, isotopic experiments at almost complete ethanol conversion allow one to avoid the overlapping of ethanol peak at m/e =46 with the same peak corresponding to C16O18O. As a result we were able to register reliably the changes of isotopic composition of acetic acid and carbon dioxide on the base of intensities of parent peaks at m/e 60 (CH3C16O16OH), 62 (CH3C16O18OH), 64 (CH3C18O18OH), 44 (C16O16O), 46(C16O18O) and 48 (C18O18O). Isotopic fraction 18O in acetic acid (α AcOH) and CO2 ( α CO 2 ) was calculated by following equations: α CH 3 COOH = I 62 + 2 × I 64 2 × ( I 60 + I 62 + I 64 ) α CO 2 = I 46 + 2 × I 48 2 × ( I 44 + I 46 + I 48 ) As to SSITKA study on the M2 phase, the intensities of m/e 60, 62, 64 were at noise-level due to a low concentration of acetic acid, peak of acetaldehyde at m/e 44 overlapped with the same peak corresponding to C16O16O. As consequence, we were not able to determine the isotopic composition of either acetic acid or carbon dioxide on this sample. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Phase composition The synthesized samples of Mo-V-Te-Nb oxide catalysts contained more than 95% of orthorhombic phase M1, or hexagonal M2, or tetragonal phase denoted as Me5O14 (Me – Mo, V, Nb) having Mo5O14-like structure. Table 1 shows physical and chemical properties of samples after their high temperature treatment. 3.2 Isotopic oxygen exchange Figs. 1a, 2a and 3a show how the concentration of isotope oxygen molecules 16O2, 16O18O and 18O2 changes during the thermally programmed isotopic oxygen exchange (TPIE) on Me5O14, M2 and M1, respectively. At T < T 0 concentrations of isotopes, observed at reactor outlet, practically coincide with their values in initial mixture. Therefore, isotopic exchange rate is too low to influence the isotopic oxygen composition in the gas phase. Temperature T0 characterizing the start of isotopic oxygen exchange follows series: M1 (460°C)>M2 (430°C)>Me5O14 (390°C). As for phases M1 and M2, similar shift of exchange starting temperature is reported elsewhere by Concepción et al. [23]. In order to reveal the heterogeneous component of isotopic exchange, i.e. gas phase oxygen exchange with the catalyst oxygen, we have plotted a dependence of atomic fraction of 18O in the gas phase oxygen on temperature. The obtained dependencies α(T) for various catalyst samples are given in Figs. 1b, 2b and 3b. Apparently (compare Fig. 1a and b), on Me5O14 isotope oxygen composition starts to change at T ≈390°C, atomic fraction of 18O in O2 being the same up to T ≈450°C. Therefore, at 390–450°C we observe only redistribution of isotopes between the gas phase oxygen molecules as occurs at homoexchange reaction (R 0): 16O2 + 18O2 =216O18O Only starting from T ≈450°C one may notice the decrease of 18O atomic fraction in the gas phase oxygen, showing heteroexchange with the catalyst, which may occur via different mechanisms R1 and R2 (for detailed discussion of exchange mechanisms R0, R1 and R2 see [24–26]): 18O2 + 16Ocat= 16O18O+ 18Ocat(R1) 18O2 + 16Ocat+ 16Ocat= 16O2 + 18Ocat+ 18Ocat(R2) Similar situation though with temperature shift is observed on phase M2: at 430–450°C only homoexchange occurs, and heteroexchange starts at T ≈450°C (see Fig. 2). As for sample M1, hetero and homo exchanges start almost simultaneously at T ≈460°C (see Fig. 3). Integrating dependence α(T), one may determine the exchanged oxygen amount in the sample: N ( O exchanged ) = 2 U C g α input 1 β ∫ T 0 T end ( α input − α ( T ) ) d T where U is the flow rate, C is oxygen concentration in the flow, β is the heating rate. Calculated values N(Oexchanged) comprising 3×1021 at/g (or 7×1020 at/m2) for Me5O14, 3×1020 at/g (0.3×1020 at/m2) for M2 and 2.5×1020 at/g (1×1020 at/m2) for M1 in all cases considerably exceed the monolayer coverage of sample surfaces (1.4×1019 at/m2). Taking into account that substitution process is not completed in these experiments, and on samples M2 and M1 it is in the starting phase only, one may assume that isotopic exchange involves the lattice oxygen of the oxide. Isotopic oxygen exchange in the oxide bulk goes according to the “relay” mechanism: propagating from the surface into the crystallite via exchange between the neighbor lattice atoms. Mostly interesting in these experiments is oxygen homoexchange. It is known that “true” oxygen homoexchange on oxides (going through the four atoms containing complex) is exclusively rare phenomenon, which may be observed at cryogenic temperatures and is characterized by activation energy close to zero. However, if very small amount of catalyst oxygen is involved into isotopic exchange, such exchange looks like homoexchange irrespectively of its actual mechanism [27]. Namely this phenomenon is observed in our experiments. Therefore, there is a small amount of oxygen on the catalyst surface, which is far more active in exchange with the gas phase oxygen than lattice oxygen. 3.3 Numerical simulation of isotopic oxygen exchange Numerical simulation of TPIE in plug flow reactor is described elsewhere (see [28,29]). In general case with several (n) variants of exchange capable catalyst oxygen, atomic fraction of 18O in the gas phase oxygen (α g ) on heating is described by the following set of equations: N g β ∂ α g ∂ T + 1 τ ∂ α g ∂ ξ = − ∑ i = 1 n W i ( α g − α s i ) N s i β ∂ α s i ∂ T = W i ( α g − α s i ) i = 1 , n Initial and boundary conditions: T = T o: α g =0, α cat =0, ξ =0: α g = α g input = 0.5 . Here N g is the number of oxygen molecules in the gas phase, W i is the rate of gas phase oxygen exchange with various type of exchange capable oxygen on the catalyst; N si and α si are the number of oxygen atoms and 18O fraction in each type of exchange capable oxygen; T is reactor temperature; β is heating rate; τ is residence time; ξ is dimensionless reactor length. In this case current fraction of 16O18O molecules in the gas phase (f 34) follows equation: N g β ∂ f 34 ∂ T + 1 τ ∂ f 34 ∂ ξ = R 0 ( 2 α g ( 1 − α g ) − f 34 ) + ∑ i = 1 n W i ( b 1 i ( 2 α s i ( 1 − α s i ) − f 34 ) + b 2 i ( α g ( 1 − α s i ) + α s i ( 1 − α g ) − f 34 ) ) T = T o : f 34 = 0 , ξ = 0 : f 34 = f 34 input = 0.05 Here R 0 is homoexchange rate, b 1i and b 2i are the contributions of mechanisms R 1 and R 2 into heteroexhange rate W i (b 1i + b 2i =1). Temperature dependences of oxygen exchange rates are expressed by Arrhenius equations: W = W ref e − ( E W / R T ′ ) , R 0 = R ref 0 e − ( E W / R T ′ ) , T ′ = T T ref T ref − T ; where W ref, R ref 0 are exchange rates at reference temperature (T ref); E is activation energy. Fig. 4 exemplifies description of experimental curves α g (T) and f 34(T) on Me5O14 according to the following model versions: I. Uniform heteroexchange, i.e. exchange with participation of one catalyst oxygen species, encompassing all lattice oxygen in the oxide (N S1 ≈1022 at/g). This version adequately describes α g (T), but fails f 34(T) description (see Fig. 4 curves 1). II. Uniform heteroexchange with lattice oxygen plus homoexchange (Fig. 4 curves 2). This version well describes both α g (T) and f 34(T). Homoexchange activation energy in this case is ≈160kJ/mol. III. Not uniform heteroexhange, providing for existence of surface oxygen essentially more active than lattice oxygen (Fig. 4 curves 3). In case when more active oxygen does not exceed 1019 atoms, this version practically coincides with the previous one. Differences lie within experimental error range (see insertion in Fig. 4). Note that in versions II and III f 34(T) description is satisfying only in case when exchange with lattice oxygen occurs via mechanism R2. Therefore, numerical analysis shows that under experimental conditions sensitivity threshold in determining exchanging oxygen amount is around 1019 atoms or 2×1019 at/g. At less amounts heteroexchange looks like homoexchange. Taking into account that calculated activation energy of homoexchange is too high, we consider the last version with two oxygen variants as the most adequately reflecting the mechanism of oxygen exchange on this type catalyst. We have used the same model for numerical analysis of TPIE on samples M1 and M2. The calculated parameters of oxygen exchange on all three catalyst samples are listed in Table 2 , while description of initial experimental dependences is given in Figs. 1–3. According to the table, difference between the values of lattice oxygen (Olat) exchange rates (W 1 ) on M1 and M2 lies within margin of error, while on sample Me5O14 W 1 is higher by an order of magnitude. Therefore, oxygen atoms in the lattice with structure Me5O14 are highly liable. As for the other catalyst oxygen variant, designated as Oads, it is characterized by the lower than on Me5O14 activation energy of exchange with O2. We may consider it as relatively weakly bonded dissociative adsorbed oxygen. Since activation energy of exchange O2 ↔Oads is similar on all samples (≈150kJ/mol), essential difference in exchange rate is most likely provided by the different concentration of Oads, which decreases in series: Me 5 O 14 ≫ M 2 > M 1 In order to reveal the role of oxygen species Olat and Oads in selective oxidation of hydrocarbons, we have in situ studied the dynamics of 18O transfer from the gas phase oxygen into the products of partial and deep oxidation. Ethanol oxidation into acetic acid has been chosen as test reaction. 3.4 SSITKA study of ethanol oxidation Conversion and selectivity toward various reaction products (acetaldehyde, acetic acid, ethyl acetate and carbon dioxide) and corresponding SSITKA conditions on M1 and Me5O14 are given in Table 3 . Data for the M2 phase are presented as well for comparison. As seen from Table 3, selectivity toward CO2 decreases in series: Me5O14 >M2>M1, in contrast total selectivity toward the products of partial oxidation reaction increased. Fig. 5 shows how atomic fraction of 18O in CH3COOH and CO2 changes after 16O2 substitution by 18O2 at steady state ethanol oxidation on Me5O14 and M1. Different dynamics of 18O transfer in CH3COOH and CO2 evidences for participation of different oxygen species in the formation of these products. According to SSITKA theory [30–32] the rate of isotopic substitution in reaction intermediates (in this case oxygen species) is inversely proportional to their concentration. Therefore, we may assume that lattice oxygen participates in CH3COOH formation, while CO2 formation is assisted by weakly bonded adsorbed oxygen, since its concentration is far lower than that of the lattice one. Under this assumption we have simulated the dynamics of 18O transfer from O2 to reaction products. Isotopic exchange rate at this temperature is negligibly small (see Fig. 1), therefore 18O fraction in the gas phase oxygen ( α O 2 ) may be considered constant and equal to that in initial mixture. Then 18O fraction in the lattice oxygen may be expressed as: d α O lat d t = − W 1 N O lat ( α O 2 − α O lat ) where N O lat and α O lat are the number of lattice oxygen atoms and 18O fraction in it; W 1 is partial oxidation rate (accounting for stoichiometry with respect to oxygen atoms). Since initial reagent ethanol contains one atom 16O, 18O fraction in CH3COOH is: α C 2 H 3 OOH = α O lat + α C 2 H 5 OH 2 = 0.5 × α O lat Number of lattice oxygen atoms N O lat is known, therefore, we may reliably calculate dependences α O lat ( t ) and α CH 3 COOH ( t ) . Changing 18O fraction in adsorbed oxygen is described by equation: d α O ads d t = − W 2 N O ads ( α O 2 − α O ads ) where N O ads and α O ads are the adsorbed oxygen amount and 18O fraction in it; W 2 is deep oxidation rate. Fraction of 18O in CO2 ( α CO 2 ) may change from 0.5 × α O ads (in case of step-wise mechanism) to 0.75 × α O ads (in case of simultaneous mechanism). We do not know the adsorbed oxygen concentration – only its upper limit estimate (2×1019 at/g). Therefore, it this case we may calculate only minimum α CO 2 ( t ) values. Calculated α CH 3 COOH 2 ( t ) and α CO 2 ( t ) are shown in Fig. 5. Apparently (see Fig. 5) calculated curve α C 2 H 3 OOH ( t ) coincides with experimental one. Therefore, exactly as assumed, lattice oxygen participates in selective ethanol oxidation into acetic acid. As for deep oxidation situation is not unambiguous. Minimum values α CO 2 ( t ) , calculated under our assumption, exceed experimental ones, especially in the case of phase M1. This means that not only adsorbed but also lattice oxygen takes part in the deep oxidation of ethanol. On phase Me5O14 weakly bonded adsorbed oxygen provides main contribution to the deep oxidation process. On phase M1, characterized by the very low concentration of adsorbed oxygen, CO2 is formed by the expense of lattice oxygen. However, selectivity towards CO2 on this sample is low and attains 6%. Therefore, according to SSITKA results weakly adsorbed oxygen is responsible for deep ethanol oxidation. Lattice oxygen conduces to reaction mainly towards partial oxidation, but also participates in deep oxidation processes. According to [33], the lower is lattice oxygen bond energy in MoVMe catalysts, the more active are they in deep oxidation. Therefore, regarding the role of oxygen in selective oxidation, we may conclude that that higher selectivity of phase M1 in comparison to Me5O14 in ethanol partial oxidation is provided by a combination of factors: first, by the low concentration of weakly bonded adsorbed oxygen, and second, by the higher energy of lattice oxygen bonds. As M2 phase, concentration of weakly bonded oxygen therein is higher than on M1 and substantially lower than on Me5O14, while the values of the energies of lattice oxygen bonds are ordered as follows: M1≅M2>Me5O14. As the result, intermediate value of selectivity to partial products is characteristic for M2 (M1>M2>Me5O14). We assume that same factors determine the selectivity of propane, propylene and acrolein oxidation [4]. 4 Conclusion Participation of different surface oxygen species on oxides in formation of partial and deep oxidation products is widely assumed in the reference literature. However, as for the Mo-V-Te-Nb oxide catalysts, up to now this assumption had no direct proof. In the present study dissociatively adsorbed oxygen has been registered on the surface of this catalyst, which is relatively weakly bonded in comparison to the lattice oxygen. In situ investigations have shown that this adsorbed oxygen participates only in deep oxidation, while lattice oxygen takes part mainly in partial oxidation. Weakly bonded oxygen concentration increases in series: M1 (orthorhombic phase)<M2 (hexagonal phase)<Mo5−x (V/Nb) x O14 (layered phase). Deep oxidation rate increases in the same consequence and thus reaction selectivity towards desired product decreases. coredata.dc:description: Isotopic oxygen exchange on the surface of Mo-V-Te-Nb oxide catalysts was studied. Catalyst samples contained more than 95% of (i) orthorhombic phase M1, (ii) pseudo hexagonal phase M2, or (iii) layered phase with structure Me5O14 (Me – Mo, V, Nb). Two forms of exchangeable oxygen were found on the surface, i.e. strongly bonded lattice oxygen and relatively weakly bonded adsorbed oxygen. According to in situ studies with isotope 18O adsorbed oxygen leads to deep oxidation products, while lattice oxygen participates mainly in the partial oxidation processes. Weakly bonded oxygen concentration decreases in series: Me5O14 >M2>M1 and thus selectivity towards partial oxidation increases.
coredata.dc:title: Mo-V-Te-Nb oxide catalysts: Reactivity of different oxygen species in partial and deep oxidation
